headline: Weekly market outlook: energy taints august inflation
content:
WEEKLY MARKET Energy Taints August Inflation

Inside Economics Podcast: All told, we are still sticking to our baseline assumption that the Fed is done with interest-
rate hikes for the current tightening cycle. The central bank views the labor market as the
primary battleground in its fight against inflation, and signs are mounting that the labor
market is indeed cooling. Fed funds pricing data suggest only a 3% probability of the
central bank moving again in September.

back against sharp increases in auto insurance rates.
Sales are slowing, earnings are trending negative, qualified
labor is hard to get, and credit access is tight. Plans to make
capital investments remain positive but are starting to pull
back, and only a thin majority of firms believe now is a good
time to expand. Small businesses may be in a good position
to ride the wave of resilience for at least the next several
months, but growth prospects are limited.
Overall, it seems they are already riding the wave. If we
break apart the index into its “hard” and “soft” components,
it is clear that expectations are weighing down the headline.
The NFIB defines the hard data components as plans to
increase employment, job openings, inventory plans,
Despite the upside surprise, core CPI inflation is earnings trends, and capital expenditure plans. Soft data
decelerating. Annualized over the past three and six months, components are expected business conditions, outlook on
the core CPI is up 2.4% and 3.7%, respectively. On a year- expansion, expected real sales, expected credit conditions,
ago basis, the core CPI is 4.4% higher. All these growth rates and assessment of current inventories. The hard data
are well below their peaks in the prior two years. Moreover, suggest that small businesses are faring as well as they were
the three-month annualized change in the core CPI is before the pandemic, though not as well as just following
roughly consistent with the Fed’s target and represents the the crisis.
slowest pace since March 2021.

Immigration to the Rescue
By DANTE DEANTONIO
U.S. job gains have throttled back in recent months. At the crawl. Unfavorable demographic headwinds are weighing
same time, we’ve seen continued buoyant growth in the heavily against participation in the native-born population,
labor force, as participation by prime-age workers and but improvement in labor force participation for foreign-born
immigration have fully recovered from the pandemic. This workers has improved dramatically as the impact of the
rebalancing of labor demand and labor supply have provided pandemic moves further into the rearview and immigration
some relief from what was a red-hot labor market. levels normalize. Prior to the pandemic, participation rates
for native-born residents aged 25-64 were consistently
higher than their foreign-born counterparts. However, that
gap narrowed significantly over the last 18 months, with
foreign-born participation hitting a new high in August as it
moved ahead of native-born participation.
Moreover, workers are no longer rushing to quit their jobs at
the record pace of a year or so ago. The quit rate—the
percent of the labor force voluntarily leaving jobs—has fallen
to where it was pre-pandemic.
The rebalancing of supply and demand, along with the
reduction in the quit rate, have resulted in slower wage Even more impressive is that foreign-born residents have
growth. Labor compensation as measured by accounted for more than 80% of the total gain in the age
the employment cost index, which controls for the changing 25-64 labor force over the past year despite representing just
mix of industries and occupations, increased just over 4% 20% of the overall labor force.
annualized in the second quarter. This is down from a recent
5.5% peak and is closing in on the 3.5% pace thought to be As the Fed remains keyed-in on moderating wage growth as
consistent with the Federal Reserve’s 2% inflation target and a critical path toward getting inflation back to its 2% target,
underlying productivity growth of 1.5% per annum. it’s important not to lose sight of the underlying labor
market dynamics that will help get there. Any significant
Key to ensuring that this moderation continues is further pullback in the pace of immigration will make it less likely
slackening of the labor market—which is most likely to result that labor supply can keep pace with labor demand, causing
from steady growth in the labor force as job gains slow to a the labor market to tighten further and putting additional
pressure on wage growth.

MOODY’S ANALYTICS CAPITAL MARKETS RESEARCH / WEEKLY MARKET OUTLOOK 11THE LONG VIEW: ASIA-PACIFIC
A Little Shine in Japan’s Q2 Growth Numbers
By STEFAN ANGRICK
Japan’s economy grew more slowly than initially expected in
the second quarter. Continuing a streak of fairly large
revisions, the updated estimate showed output rising 1.2%
quarter on quarter, 0.3 percentage point less than in the
initial estimate. Typically, the second estimate is within 0.1
to 0.2 percentage point of the first reading. Growth in the
second quarter was surprisingly strong, notwithstanding
Friday's downward revision. But the glossy top-line figure
masked significant weakness in domestic demand and a
fragile outlook for the quarters ahead.
The revision was largely due to weaker business investment
and private consumption results. Private consumption
shaved 0.4 percentage point off growth, compared with 0.3 With household and business spending falling, it’s hard to
before. Business investment fell on the quarter, shaving 0.2 escape the impression that Japan’s post-pandemic recovery
percentage point off growth. The initial estimate showed has fizzled out prematurely.
capex spending unchanged from the first quarter. The latest
survey of corporate financial statements—which factors into As domestic weakness adds to an unsteady external
the second estimate of GDP—showed that capital backdrop, GDP may lose recent gains in the quarters ahead.
expenditure fell more than expected. Spending by The fall in imports in the second quarter was an anomaly by
nonmanufacturers was particularly weak. Government historical standards and is not likely to repeat. The recovery
investment was also revised down, continuing a trend of in goods exports and tourism has largely run its course. And
disappointing results that raises questions about progress on with China’s economy stuck in low gear and U.S. consumers
the government’s various investment plans. Private looking for holidays rather than goods, prospects for a
residential investment, government consumption and net renewed bounce in exports look slim. Household spending
exports were broadly unchanged. will struggle while wages trail inflation.
The revised estimate confirms that growth in the second
stanza was driven almost entirely by better net exports. The
fading impact of supply-chain disruptions helped lift
shipments of goods, particularly cars, while the resurgence
of foreign visitors coming to Japan boosted service exports.
But most of the improvement in net exports was due to
dwindling imports—hardly an indicator of an economy that
is humming along.
Broader weakness in demand will cap investment gains. All
of this points to a fragile outlook which, in principle, speaks
against monetary policy tweaks. But given the Bank of
Japan’s recent strategy of “signalling left, turning right”,
surprises are a risk.
